newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila shares end up but off intra-day high.
newsitem.headline: Manila shares end up but off intra-day high.

text.p: Philippine shares ended higher for the third straight session amid light turnover on Friday despite a mild wave of profit-taking in late trading, brokers said.
"There is no more negative news, so far, so the market reacted (positively)," said Harry Liu, president at Summit Securities.
The main index closed 11.51 points higher, or 0.44 percent, at 2,598.20. The index reached its intra-day high of 2,624.82 shortly after the opening bell.
"Early on, the focus was on secondary and blue-chip issues. But the stars of the day were thirdliners," one dealer said.
Traders said steady U.S. interest rates, improved first quarter agricultural growth and an absence of bad news prodded the recent uptick although volumes have been low.

"I still think it's premature to say we are on the road to full recovery. Government is trying to paint a strong first quarter macroeconomic picture. There are some positioning on blue chips but overall, the volume is thin," said Saturnino Mejia, research head at Guoco Securities Phils Inc.
Turnover was light at 1.86 billion pesos, below the daily average of between 2.7 billion and 2.9 billion pesos.
Philippine TA Securities Inc said a sustained climb in share prices was unlikely unless supported by heavier volume, better corporate financial results and a positive first quarter GNP.
